body:
@tobb10001 Thx for raising this issue. I was looking into it and think that actually there is no bug. Reason is that `make_reduction` is doing the tabularization of the time series and therefore some past values of `y` go into `X`. You will see that doing following will therefore also raise the same exception.
```pyhton
model.fit(y_w_nan)
```
The `X` is internally created to the lags:
```
array([[   nan, 61122., 60171., 61187., 63221., 63639., 64989., 63761.,
        66019., 67857.],
       [61122., 60171., 61187., 63221., 63639., 64989., 63761., 66019.,
        67857., 68169.],
       [60171., 61187., 63221., 63639., 64989., 63761., 66019., 67857.,
        68169., 66513.],
       [61187., 63221., 63639., 64989., 63761., 66019., 67857., 68169.,
        66513., 68655.],
       [63221., 63639., 64989., 63761., 66019., 67857., 68169., 66513.,
        68655., 69564.],
       [63639., 64989., 63761., 66019., 67857., 68169., 66513., 68655.,
        69564., 69331.]])
```

I can understand that the exception might be a little confusing. We could write a custom exception around this, but actually I am not a big fan of wrapping exceptions. Or what do you have in mind? @tobb10001 :)

@fkiraly @tobb10001  I am wondering if the order of the `X` values per row should not be inverted? I think for tree-based models it doesnt matter but for liner models I think it matters? So first row would start with `67857.` and end with `nan`?
The `y` is originally:
```
Period
1947        NaN
1948    61122.0
1949    60171.0
1950    61187.0
1951    63221.0
1952    63639.0
1953    64989.0
1954    63761.0
1955    66019.0
1956    67857.0
1957    68169.0
1958    66513.0
1959    68655.0
1960    69564.0
1961    69331.0
1962    70551.0
Freq: A-DEC, Name: TOTEMP, dtype: float64
```

rename.from: [BUG] make_regression causes misleading Exception on NaN values: `ValueError: Input X contains NaN.`
rename.to: [BUG] make_reduction causes misleading Exception on NaN values: `ValueError: Input X contains NaN.`

body:
@aiwalter I've got a few things in mind, but none of which seems convincing...

I think the cleanes would be to to somehow check if the passed estimator can handle NaNs and if it doesn't, check `y` and `X` in sktime, before passing it to the estimator. However, I'm afraid that this is impossible.
The only thing I've found is a [small list of estimators that _are_ capable of handling NaNs](https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/impute.html#estimators-that-handle-nan-values) in sklearn, but I don't think this can be used to build a stable mechanism.

Another approach would be to catch the exception, check if it says `Input X contains NaN.` and emit a warning or something But I don't like this approach as well, because (a) one would probably not read the warning anyways, if there is an exception right besides it and (b) reading a string intended for humans will probably never be stable (maybe another regressor says `NaN found in X input`...).
(b) also applies for wrapping / reraising the exception as well, so I wouldn't consider this an option as well...

Maybe a note in the documentation to also check your `y` if you see this exception might be the best option. Although admitted, that I think I didn't even look there when I encountered this yesterday...

> I think the cleanes would be to to somehow check if the passed estimator can handle NaNs and if it doesn't, check y and X in sktime, before passing it to the estimator. However, I'm afraid that this is impossible.

I think that's incorrect.

That is, it is possible to check whether the wrapped estimator can handle nan, via the `sklearn` tag `allow_nan`.

We could copy that tag to the `sktime` estimator for the same purpose, which would then raise an informative error message, in theory (at the input checks).

issue.title: [ENH] missing data input check in forecasters

repository.name: sktime
repository.description: A unified framework for machine learning with time series

issue.body:
This PR introduces missing data input checks to forecasters and fixes #3402.

Changes:
* `_check_X_y` in forecasters now raises an informative exception if input contains missing data and the forecaster does not support it
* the forecaster extension template is updated accordingly
* reducers are updated so missing value handling tags mirror the wrapped sklearn estimator's tag
* switched the tag to `True` in some estimators causing issues: `AutoETS`

body:
This should work:
https://github.com/alan-turing-institute/sktime/pull/3405

I also noticed the input checks of forecasters did not check missing values in data against the tag - the PR #3405 also adds an informative error message.

seems to work, but there might be some interaction with `WindowSummarizer` - @danbartl, any idea what might be happening? It seems the reducer in the pipeline is receiving NAs from `WindowSummarizer` - is that expected?
@fkiraly sorry do not get your comment, what do you mean by "seems the reducer in the pipeline is receiving NAs from WindowSummarizer"? I do not see WindowSummarizer in the example
In the PR that adds the NA error message, PR #3405, one of the regression tests that involves it fails, because `WindowSummarizer` produces NA for some reason where it is unexpected. I think?
